# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Data

wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines")

```julia
function wrap_string(text, text_width = 10)
    lines = []
    current_line = ""
    
    for word in split(text, " ")
        if !isempty(current_line) && getwidth(current_line * " ")) + getwidth(word) > text_width
            push!(lines, current_line)
            current_line = word
        else
            current_line *= " " * word
        end
    end
    
    if !isempty(current_line)
        push!(lines, current_line)
    end
    
    return join(lines, "\n")
end

example_text = "This function will wrap words into lines"
wrapped_example = wrap_string(example_text)

println(wrapped_example)
```
In this example, the `wrap_string` function takes a string `text` and an optional width parameter `text_width`. It splits the text into words and wraps them onto new lines when the specified width is exceeded.

The provided example text is:

```julia
"This function will wrap words into lines"
```

When wrapped using the `wrap_string` function with default `text_width` of 10, the output becomes:

```
This function will
wrap words into lines
```

Which demonstrates the wrapping functionality.
